note.label: Alice Wandesford Thornton
note.desc: Alice Wandesford (1626-1707) was born to Christopher Wandesford – later Lord Deputy of Ireland – and his wife Alice Osborne in Kirklington, North Yorkshire on 13 February 1626. She was their fifth child of seven, and their youngest daughter. The family relocated to Dublin in the 1630s when Wandesford's friend and mentor Thomas Wentworth, 1st Lord Strafford, became Lord Deputy of Ireland. Wandesford succeeded Wentworth in 1640 but died that same year, and the family located back to Yorkshire during the Civil War. She married William Thornton of East Newton in 1651, and they had nine children, three of whom survived to adulthood: Alice (Nally), Katherine and Robert. William Thornton died in 1668. Alice wrote three autobiographies, ('Books of my Life') and a Book of Remembrances. She died in 1707 at East Newton and is buried at Stonegrave.

note.label: Christopher Wandesford
note.desc: Sir Christopher Wandesford (1592-1640) was the eldest son and heir of George Wandesford and Catherine Hansby. He was born at Bishop Burton, East Riding, on 24 September 1592. He attended Clare College but was required to return home on his father's death to provide for his siblings. He married Alice Osborne and they had seven children, five of whom survived childhood. He was MP for Yorkshire in the 1620s, and in 1633 relocated the family to Dublin, Ireland, to serve as Master of Rolls under his childhood friend, Thomas Wentworth 1st Earl Strafford, who had been made Lord Deputy of Ireland. On Wentworth's death in 1640 Wandesford was briefly Lord Deputy before he died at 48 years old on 3 December 1640.

note.label: Roger Lasselles
note.desc: Roger Lasscelles, or Lascelles (1557-1630), was rector of Kirklington from 19 May 1590 until his death in July 1630. He baptised Alice Wandesford Thornton at Kirklington in February 1626.

note.label: Anne Wandesford Norton
note.desc: Anne Norton was Alice Thornton’s aunt. She married Maulger Norton on 4 March 1622. They had five children; three sons and two daughters.

note.label: Mrs Best
note.desc: Mrs Best was probably Olive Mallory (1594-1654), daughter of John and Anne Mallory, baptised in 16 June 1594. She became the second wife of Thomas Best of Middleton Quernhow, M.P. for Ripon on 17 January 1619. She had a twin sister, Jane. She died without issue and was buried on 16 June 1654.

note.label: Sarah Tomlinson
note.desc: Sarah Tomlinson was a servant in Alice's household.

note.label: Christopher Wandesford
note.desc: Christopher Wandesford (1628-87), 1st Baronet of Kirklington, was the son of Sir Christopher Wandesford and Alice Osborn, and was born on 2 February 1628. He was Alice Thornton's younger brother. He married Eleanor Lowther on 30 September 1651, and they had 12 children. He became family heir on his brother George’s death in 1651, and was made Baronet on the Restoration in 1660. He was elected MP for Ripon in 1679 and again in 1680. He died in London on 23 February 1687.

note.label: Mr Baxter
note.desc: In 1631 Alice and Christopher Wandesford, then children, were sent with their maid Sarah to Mr. Baxter's house in Kent to recover from smallpox. The Wandesford family were living in London at the time.

note.label: Lady Leverton ?
note.desc: Lady Katherine Leveson (1598-1674) was the daughter of the illegitimate son of the Elizabethan courtier Robert Dudley, also called Robert Dudley, and his first wife Alice Leigh, born 1598. She married Sir Richard Leveson of Shropshire, elected MP for Newcastle-under-Lyme in 1640. She died in 1674 without issue, and endowed almshouses and an education fund which survives to this day at Temple Balsall.

note.label: Thomas Wentworth, earl of Strafford
note.desc: Thomas Wentworth, 1st Lord Raby, 1st Earl Strafford (1593-1641), was Lord Lieutenant of Ireland 1633-40. He was born on 13 April 1593 to William Wentworth, a Yorkshire landowner, and Anne Atkinson – their second and eldest surviving son and heir. He was a childhood friend of Christopher Wandesford, Alice's father, both being educated by the Dean of Ripon. His first marriage to Margaret Clifford took place in 1611, she died childless in August 1622. He married Arabella Holles in February 1625, then had a son and two daughters. After her premature death on 6 October 1631 he married Elizabeth Rodes in 1632 and had another son and a daughter. In 1633 he was made Lord Deputy of Ireland and relocated to Dublin, with the Wandesford family in tow as Christopher was made Master of the Rolls. He was recalled to England in 1639, fell out of favour with the King, impeached and executed on 12 May 1641.

persName.roleName: Sir, 1st Lord Raby; 1st Earl of Strafford

note.label: Lady Anne Wentworth
note.desc: Lady Anne Wentworth (1627-96) was the eldest daughter of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford and his second wife Arabella Holles, born in October 1627. A childhood friend of Alice Thornton's in Dublin, she married Edward Watson on 24 November 1654 and they had two sons and two daughters. She died on 2 January 1696.

note.label: Lady Arbella Wentworth
note.desc: Lady Arabella Wentworth (1630-89) was the daughter of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford and Arabella Holles. A childhood friend of Alice Thornton's in Dublin, she married Justin MacCarthy, who was about 13 years her junior. She died in 1689 without issue.

note.label: John Wandesford
note.desc: John Wandesford (c. 1632-1664) was the fourth, but third surviving, son of Christopher and Alice Osborne, and the brother of Alice Wandesford, born c. 1632. He was educated at Bedale, Chester and Richmond Schools before entering Christ's College, Cambridge (1649-51). Becoming ill at Cambridge, according to Alice in reaction to the death of their brother George, he moved to London. He was elected MP for Richmond in 1661 after he successfully petitioned the election of Joseph Cradock, disqualified on account of being an ecclesiastic. He died in his lodgings at Richmond on 2 December 1664, of an ague.

note.label: Frank Kelly
note.desc: Frank Kelly (c. 1634-43) was an orphan boy taken into the household of Sir Christopher Wandesford in Dublin, after Wandesford had encountered him while playing bowls on the green. According to Alice he was about 9 when he died of small pox at Chester after the family had fled Ireland, meaning he was born c. 1634.

note.label: Thomas Danby
note.desc: Thomas Danby of South Cave (d. 1645)was the second son of Thomas Danby of Braworth. He was involved in a court of chivalry case in 1638 against John Bates of York, whom Danby claimed had verbally abused him and denied his gentility. He fought for the Royalists during the Civil War and was killed at the Battle of Naseby on 14 June 1645.

note.label: Mr Mahum
note.desc: Dr Mahum, described by Alice as her 'old doctor', may be the same Richard Mahum who witnessed her mother's will in 1659.

note.label: Katherine Wandesford Danby
note.desc: Katherine Wandesford Danby (1615-45): eldest child of Christopher Wandesford and Alice Osborne Wandesford; sister of Alice Thornton. Born in 1615. Married Thomas Danby, who was in the service of the Lord Deputy of Ireland, c. 1630. She was pregnant 16 times but only carried 10 to term, and of these 8 were boys and 2 were girls. Died 10 Sept. 1645 at her house in Thorp, as a result of childbirth. Buried at Masham 11 Sept. 1645.

note.label: Francis Danby
note.desc: Francis Danby (born 3 September 1645); youngest son of Thomas Danby and Katherine Wandesford; Alice Wandesford's nephew. Named after his brother who died as a baby the previous year, his mother Katherine died from post-partum complications a few days after his birth.

note.label: Edmund Norton
note.desc: Edmund Norton (born 1622); second son of Maulger Norton and Anne Wandesford; Alice Wandesford Thornton's cousin. Attended Cambridge University and admitted to Gray's Inn in 1645/46. He married Jane Dudley. Died of a pleurisy at York in 1648.

note.label: Toby Dudley
note.desc: Toby Dudley (b. 1597) was the oldest son and heir of Ambrose Dudley of Chopwell, Northumberland. He married Jane Blackiston, and they had one child, Jane. He was buried at Ryton in 1661.

note.label: Jane Dudley Norton
note.desc: Jane Dudley Norton was the daughter and sole heir of Toby Dudley of Chopwell. She married Edmund Norton on 10 February 1647. He died in 1648. Her second husband was Robert Clavering who she married at Ebchester on 15 July 1651. They had three children. She died in 1672.

note.label: Charles I
note.desc: Charles I of England (born 19 November 1600), King of England, Scotland and Ireland from 1625, was the reigning monarch for the first 23 years of Alice Thornton's life. He was executed on 30 January 1649.

note.label: Julian Norton
note.desc: Julian (or Gillian) was the daughter of Maulger and Anne Norton (Alice's aunt). She was born in 1632 and so was only 17 when she died on 9 April 1649 at her father's house at Richmond.

note.label: John Norton
note.desc: John Norton (1637-1646), son of Maulger Norton and Anne Wandesford, died at his father's residence at St Nicholas, Richmond of a consumption, aged 9.

note.label: Sir Edward Osborne
note.desc: Sir Edward Osbornee, 1st Baronet Kiveton (1596-1647) was baptised on 12 December 1596, the son of Sir Hewett Osborne and Joyce Fleetwood. He was brother of Alice Osborne Wandesford and the uncle of Alice Thornton.

note.label: George Wandesford
note.desc: George Wandesford (born 14 September 1623) was Christopher Wandesford and Alice Osborne's eldest son and heir. Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford was his godfather. He attended Trinity College, Dublin from 1636. Accused of taking part in the battle of Marston Moor in July 1644, his estates were sequestered, and so he moved back to live at Hipswell, his mother's property. He drowned in the River Swale, Yorkshire, through which he was riding on horseback, on 31 March 1651, on the way to visit his cousin William Wandesford.

note.label: William Wandesford
note.desc: William Wandesford (1605-90) was baptised in 26 August 1605 at Kirklington, the youngest son of Sir George Wandesford by his second wife, Mary Pamplyn. He was Alice Thornton's half-uncle. He married Rebecca Reade. His brother Christopher sent him to be an apprentice to a London merchant. He was granted an annuity of £20 for life on 30 June 1637 out of his property at Castlecomer, Ireland and paid yearly at Christ's Church, Dublin. He suffered severe losses during the civil war due to his loyalty to the royal cause, and on 31 July 1646 he declared he had been at Oxford when Castlecomer was held for the king, and that he lent money but had not taken up arms. He was made a gentleman-pensioner by Charles II after the Restoration in 1660 and died in 1690 aged 85.

note.label: Mary Norton Yorke
note.desc: Mary Norton, daughter and fourth child of Maulger Norton and Anne Wandesford, was baptised at Richmond on 12 July 1635; she was Alice Thornton's cousin. On 20 August 1651 she married John Yorke, a knight of Gouthwaite, later MP for Richmond (1661-63). They had four children; three sons and a daughter.

note.label: John Yorke
note.desc: Sir John Yorke (c. 1634-63) was the son of John Yorke of Gouthwaite and his second wife, Catherine Daniell of Beswick. He was educated at Queen's College, Oxford, matriculating in 1650. On 20 August 1651 he married Mary Norton, daughter of Maulger Norton and Anne Wandesford. He was knighted by Charles II on his Restoration in 1660, and elected MP for Richmond at the Cavalier Parliament the next year, a position he held until his death near London on 1 April 1663 aged 29. He held several offices during his time as MP. He is buried in St Chad's Church, Middlesmoor in Nidderdale, commemorated by a Latin inscription.

note.label: Sir John Lowther
note.desc: Sir John Lowther, 1st Baronet Lowther (1606-75) and Sheriff of Cumberland was born on 20 February 1606 to Sir John Lowther and his wife Eleanor Fleming. He graduated from the Inner Temple in 1621 and was called to the bar in 1630. He married Mary Fletcher, daughter of Richard Fletcher of Hutton, Cumbria, before 1628; they had 11 children – 5 sons and 6 daughters. His second wife was Elizabeth Hare, by whom he had four children, three sons and a daughter. His daughter Eleanor married Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton's brother. He was twice elected to the constituency of Westmorland, in 1628-29 (with his father) and in 1660. He fought with the royalists during the Civil War. He died on 30 November 1675 and is buried at Lowther Church alongside his father, commemorated by a Latin inscription.

persName.roleName: Sir, Sheriff of Cumberland, 1st Baronet Lowther

note.label: Eleanor Lowther Wandesford
note.desc: Eleanor Lowther (bap. 23 March 1633 at Lowther) was the daughter of John Lowther, 1st Baronet Lowther and his first wife Mary Fletcher. She married Christopher Wandesford on 30 September 1651 at Lowther, making her Alice Thornton's sister-in-law. They had nine children, three sons and six daughters. She was buried on 20 December 1714 at Kirklington.

note.label: William Thornton
note.desc: William Thornton, the son of Robert Thornton of East Newton and his second wife Elizabeth Darley, was baptized at Stonegrave church on 9 June 1624. He had a twin brother, Richard. William married Alice Wandesford on 15 December 1651 at Hipswell. They had nine children, of whom three survived to adulthood. William died and was buried on 18 September 1668 at Stonegrave. William's arms are part of the wall ornament in Stonegrave church, in the North Riding of Yorkshire.

note.label: Michael Syddall
note.desc: Michael Syddall was vicar of Catterick.

note.label: Unnamed Thornton daughter ?
note.desc: Alice Thornton's first child, an unnamed daughter, was born on 27 August 1652 but only lived for fifteen minutes. She was buried at Easby Church the next day.

note.label: Alice Thornton Comber
note.desc: Alice Comber, called Nally, was born in 1654 to Alice and William Thornton. She was their second child but first born alive, and one of three of the Thornton children to survive to adulthood. She married Thomas Comber in 1668, by whom she had six children, four sons and two daughters. Nally's marriage to Comber was at the centre of the slanders against the Thornton family spearheaded by Nally's cousin-by-marriage Anne Danby. Nally was very young – 14 – when she married Comber. Other rumours possibly centred on Nally's mother relationship with Comber, who had been living with the family at East Newton since 1665 when he took up the curacy of Stonegrave. She died on 20 January 1721.

note.label: Maulger Norton
note.desc: Maulger Norton (1593-1673) was the first son and heir of Robert Norton of St. Nicholas, Richmond and his wife Catherine Staveley. He was elected MP for Richmond in the Short Parliament of 1640. He married Alice Thornton's aunt Anne Wandesford, by whom he had 5 children, 3 sons and 2 daughters. He was buried at Richmond on 12 December 1673.

note.label: Elizabeth Thornton
note.desc: Elizabeth (Betty) Thornton (born 14 February 1654) was Alice Wandesford Thornton's third, and second surviving, child. She died on 5 September 1656, aged two, after becoming ill with an ague.

note.label: Charles Anthony
note.desc: Charles Anthony (ordained 1636) became vicar of Catterick. He baptised Alice Thornton's daughter Elizabeth in 1654. He died in 1685 and was buried at Catterick.

note.label: Katherine Blackburne
note.desc: Katherine Covell Blackburne was the daughter of Roger Covell and Anne Norton. She married Timothy Blackburne. She stood in for Alice Thornton's mother, who was unwell, at Alice's daughter Elizabeth's baptism in 1654.

note.label: Elizabeth Darley Thornton Gates
note.desc: Elizabeth Darley (born 3 October 1597) was the eldest daughter of Sir Richard Darley of Buttercrambe, Yorkshire and his second wife, Elizabeth Gates. She became the second wife of Robert Thornton (c. 1560-1637) c. 1620 and they had seven children, four sons and three daughters. After his death she married Gefferey Gates. Her eldest son William married Alice Wandesford. She died on 10 May 1655 at Oswoldkirk, from a 'voydance of blood' and was buried the next day at Stonegrave.

note.label: Gefferey Gates
note.desc: Gefferey Gates was the second husband of Elizabeth Darley Thornton and the stepfather of Alice Wandesford's husband William Thornton. He died just 8 days after his wife, 18 May 1655, and was buried at Hull the same day.

note.label: Richard Thornton
note.desc: Richard Thornton was the twin brother of Alice Wandesford's husband William Thornton. He died unmarried in Dublin, Ireland of a bloody flux on 3 July 1656. He was buried at St. Patrick's Church the next day.

note.label: Katherine Thornton Purchase Danby
note.desc: Katherine (Kat, Katy) Thornton was the fourth daughter of Alice Thornton and William Thornton, and the second of two surviving daughters. She was born on 12 June 1656 at Hipswell. She married Thomas Purchase by arrangement of her brother-in-law Thomas Comber on 17 December 1682, and after his death in 1696 she married Robert Danby. She had seven children by Thomas, four sons and three daughters. She died on 17 December 1726 and was buried at Stonegrave.

note.label: Katherine Danby Best
note.desc: Katherine Danby (born 1637) to Katherine Wandesford and Thomas Danby; Alice Thornton's niece. She married Henry Best of Middleton Quernhow, a Gray's Inn Barrister, some time after 1659, and they had two children, Katherine and Henry. She was eventually sole heiress to her father, and was his administratrix on 29 January 1673/4. His will gave her £2,000. She died in 1688.

note.label: Unnamed Thornton son ?
note.desc: Alice Thornton's fifth child, an unnamed son, was born on 10 December 1657, but lived only half an hour after a difficult birth. He was buried at Catterick the same day by Michael Syddall.

note.label: Dr Robert Wittie
note.desc: Robert Wittie was baptised at St. Mary's, Beverley, on 14 November 1613, the son of George Wittie of Beverley and Anne Howard. He studied medicine at King's College, Cambridge, and returned to his native Yorkshire to practice medicine, first at Hull, and from 1651 at the latest, at York. He appears frequently in Alice Thornton's books, treating various ailments of her and her family. Wittie married Mary Hall (d. 1691/2). In 1675, when his mother died, he was resident in the parish of St. Martin's, Coney-street. On his retirement from active profession he moved to London and was incorporated at the Royal College of Physicians on 30 September 1680. He died in October 1684.

note.label: Alice Osborne Wandesford
note.desc: Alice Osborne Wandesford was born in 1593, the daughter of Hewet Osborne of Kniveton and Joyce Fleetwood; Alice Thornton's mother. She was the second wife of Sir Christopher Wandesford, and by him had seven children, of which five survived to adulthood. She joined her husband in Dublin with her young children in 1633, when he accompanied Thomas Wentworth there and became Master of the Rolls. Later made Lord Deputy of Ireland, he died in 1640, after which Alice and her children fled an extremely hostile Ireland by boat back to Yorkshire, where she spent the next two decades at Hipswell. She died on 10 December 1659 after falling ill on 17 November, and was buried at Catterick Church.

note.label: Dr Peter Samways
note.desc: Peter Samways was born at Eltham, Kent, in 1615, the son of a ‘person about the court.’ He was educated at Westminster School and then Trinity College, Cambridge, where he then became one of the college tutors until 1650. During his residence at Cambridge he contributed verses to the university collections royalist poems. In or before 1657 he became rector of Malden, Bedfordshire, and in 1659 he was chaplain to Elizabeth, countess of Peterborough. He was presented by Lord Salisbury to the vicarage of Cheshunt, Hertfordshire, from which he was expelled by the parliamentary visitors because he persisted in reading the liturgy of the church of England, when he was also deprived of his fellowship at Trinity. After the Restoration he was created D.D. at Cambridge, by royal mandate, on 5 Sept. 1660, but he was not reinstated in his benefice at Cheshunt, probably because, on 31 Dec. 1660, he was presented to the rectory of Wath, near Ripon, Yorkshire, worth about 140l. per annum, by the Earl of Aylesbury, in whose family he had spent some time during the rebellion. Soon afterwards he was presented by Charles II to the neighbouring rectory of Bedale, worth nearly 600l. a year. It was during the late 1650s and 1660s that Samways appears in Alice's books, attending the final illness of her mother Alice Osborne in December 1659. According to Alice, he was one of the people taken in by the rumours begun by Anne Danby about her daughter Nally's marriage to Thomas Comber in 1668. He was a great benefactor to the parish of Wath, where he built and endowed a school. On 27 May 1668 he was collated to the prebend of Barneby in the church of York. He was a staunch supporter of the church of England, and it is recorded of him that he boldly disputed the doctrine of transubstantiation with the Duke of York (afterwards James II). He fell under the displeasure of Bishop Cartwright, then administering the see of York, by refusing to subscribe the king's declaration for liberty of conscience in 1688, and he narrowly escaped a second ejection from his benefices. Samways further aided the cause of civil and religious liberty by publishing a letter, which had a considerable effect in persuading the clergy of his neighbourhood to take the oaths to King William and Queen Mary, and for this service he is said to have received an offer of the bishopric of Bath and Wells which he declined. Among his intimate friends were Dr. Isaac Barrow and Archbishops Ussher and Sancroft. He died at Bedale in April 1693. CRIBBED AND ADAPTED FROM ODNB SO NEEDS MORE CHANGING. OR DO WE JUST CREDIT IT.

note.label: John Kearton
note.desc: John Kearton received his BA from Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge. He was ordained deacon at York in 1628, and priest in the same place in 1629. He was rector of Richmond 1657-62. Alice Osborne Wandesford wanted him to preach at her funeral service in 1659, and in April 1660 he baptised, and then shortly afterwards buried, Alice Thornton's sixth child William at Easby. He died in 1662.

note.label: Daphne Cassell Lightfoot
note.desc: Daphne Cassell entered the service of Alice Thornton's mother Alice Osborne Wandesford unmarried, but soon married George Lightfoot, also in service to Alice senior. She was with Alice's sister Katherine when she died after childbirth in 1645 and prayed with Alice's mother at her death bed in 1659. She and her husband were witnesses to Alice's mothers will. Daphne was a close friend and confidante of Alice's throughout the events Alice discusses in her books. She breastfed Alice's child Elizabeth for three months when Alice was unable to produce milk. She helped Alice with the inventory of her house when her husband died leaving debts in 1668, and was also a staunch defender of Alice's during the Danby scandal which was happening at the same time.

note.label: Conyers Darcy, Lord Darcy and Conyers
note.desc: Sir Conyers Darcy, 1st Earl of Holdernesse, 8th Lord Darcy de Knayth was born on 24 January 1598 to Sir Conyers Darcy and Dorothy Belasyse. He was constable of Middleham Castle, Yorkshire, and created Earl of Holdernesse on 6 Decemeber 1682, with remainder to the heirs male of his body. Circa 1619 he married Grace, only daughter and heir of Thomas Rokeby, of Skyers, Yorks. They had six sons and five daughters, but only one son, Conyers, survived childhood. He died on 14 June, 1689.

note.label: Hannah Ableson
note.desc: Hannah Ableson was a servant in Alice Thornton's household.

note.label: Robert Adair
note.desc: Sir Robert Adair, of Ballymenna, co. Antrim, who was served heir to his father and grandfather, in the Scotch estates on February 19 1629. He married of William Edmondstone, of Duntreath, co. Stirling. He died on 1 March, 1655, and was succeeded by his eldest son. Adair is mentioned in Thornton's first book by Captain Innes, a Scottish soldier who wished to marry Alice. In order to persuade Alice's mother to agree he offered money and a character reference from Adair.

note.label: George Anderson
note.desc: George Anderson, a Scotsman, was a tutor of Alice Thornton's brother George in France during the Civil War.

note.label: Catherine Danby Armitage
note.desc: Catherine Danby Armitage was the oldest daughter and second child of Thomas Danby of Farnley, Leeds and Elizabeth Wentworth. She married Francis Armytage in 1629 – he was created Baronet by Charles I in 1641. They had at least 11 children, five of whom, three sons and two daughters, can be identified. A widow from 1644, she attended Katherine Wandesford Danby, her sister-in-law, on her death bed in 1645. She was buried on 13 January 1666.

note.label: William Ascough
note.desc: William Ayscough of Osgoodby (born 9 March 1648) was the son of Sir William Ayscough and Judith Burgoyne. He (or perhaps his father) was one of the coffin bearers at William Thornton's funeral in September 1668, and he married Alice Thornton's sister-in-law Ann (Dorothy) Thornton in 1675/76. He died within a year of marriage and was buried on 20 November 1676 at Thirkleby.

note.label: John Ashton
note.desc: Captain John Ashton, born c. 1614, was the son of Radclyffe Ashton of Cuerdale and Elizabeth Hyde. He married Ann Shuttleworth and they had one son. He was Captain of the Foot during the Civil War. When Alice Thornton and her family fled Ireland on her father's death in 1640, it was Ashton who provided them with safe passage back home to Yorkshire from Lancashire. He died at Bristol in 1643 from wounds sustained at the Battle of Edge Hill in October 1642.

note.label: Dr Atie
note.desc: Dr Atie appears briefly in Alice's account of her mother's death, being sent to her, perhaps as a deputy, by Dr Wittie who could not attend her deathbed.

note.label: John Bathurst
note.desc: John Bathurst (born c. 1596) matriculated from Pembroke College Cambridge in 1614 and became a Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians in 1637. He was incorporated at Oxford in 1643, and acted as physician to Oliver Cromwell. He was MP for Richmond in 1656 and 1658. He married Elizabeth Willance on 27 January 1635/36. Alice Thornton's mother sent her son Christopher to Dr. Bathurst at York when he suffered a distemper from grief over his father's death in November 1643, and her brother John was likewise sent to him when he dropped out of Cambridge University and moved to London in a state of melancholy. He died in 1659.

note.label: Martha Batte
note.desc: Martha was the daughter of John Batte and Martha Mallory. She was baptised at Birstall, Yorkshire on 26 September 1636. She went to America with her father and brothers where they partook in the slave trade. By 1667 she was in the service of the Countess of Sussex at Howley Hall. She was a friend of Alice Thornton's niece-by-marriage, Anne Danby. According to Alice, Anne wanted to prevent the marriage of Thomas Comber and Nally Thornton in order for Thomas to marry Martha. Martha died in April 1668.

note.label: Henry Best
note.desc: Henry Best was the son of George Best and Grace Darcy. He married Katherine Danby, Alice Thornton’s niece, after 1659, and was referred to by Alice as 'my nephew Best'. He had two children by Katherine, also called Henry and Katherine. He was a barrister at Gray’s Inn. He died 1674.

note.label: Thomas Binks
note.desc: Thomas Binks was a poor man who warned Alice Thornton that Jeremy Smithson was plotting to abduct her after Alice refused his hand in marriage.

note.label: Mr Binlows
note.desc: Mr Binlows was one of the ministers attendant at Alice Thornton's mother's funeral in 1659.

note.label: John Borlase
note.desc: Sir John Borlase was born c. 1576 in Cornwall to Edward Borlase and Suszannah Isham. He attended Cambridge University, but did not graduate, and then pursued a military career. He fought extensively in the Low Countries in the early 17th century, becoming master-general of the ordnance of Ireland in 1634, and became Lord Justice of Ireland after the death of Christopher Wandesford in 1640 along with Sir William Parsons. He married Alice Ravis, widow of Thomas Ravis, bishop of London, and they had three sons. He died in 1648.

note.label: John Bramhall
note.desc: John Bramhall (born November 1594) was one of six children of Peter Bramhall of Carleton, Pontefract. He graduated with a BA from Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge in 1612, and was ordained in York in 1615. On 24 June 1618, Christopher Wandesford presented him to the rectory of South Kilvington, near Thirsk. On 10 November he married a clergyman's widow, Ellen Collingwood (née Halley). Wandesford and Thomas Wentworth helped Bramhall secure the prebend of Huisthwaite, Yorkshire in 1632. He became Bishop of Derry, in Ireland, in May 1634, and was present at Christopher Wandesford's deathbed in 1640. After Wandesford's death he was exiled and had returned to his native Yorkshire by 1642; and was restored in Ireland by Charles II in 1660. He died in 1663.

note.label: Cousin Branlen?
note.desc: Along with Alice Thornton and Lord Loftus, Cousin Branlen is listed as a witness to the baptism? of Alice Thornton's sister Katherine Danby's first son Francis at Middleham Castle in 1644.

note.label: Mary Breakes
note.desc: Mary Breakes was a servant in Alice Thornton's household. Mary was implicated by Anne Danby and others in spreading rumours about Alice and Nally Thornton in summer 1668.

note.label: Sir William Brereton
note.desc: Sir William Brereton, 1st Baronet, (1604–1661), was an English Puritan who owned extensive estates in Cheshire, and Member of Parliament for Cheshire county at various times between 1628 and 1653. During the First English Civil War, he was commander of Parliamentarian forces in the North Midlands. He married twice; firstly, Susanna Booth, by whom he had four children, 3 daughters and a son; and after her death Cicely Mytton, a wealthy Staffordshire widow, by whom he had two more daughters. When Christopher Wandesford's family, including a teenage Alice, fled Ireland after his death in 1640 and landed in Cheshire, they were held up on their way home to Yorkshire at Chester due to Brereton's Parliamentary forces. When the Civil War ended in 1646, Brereton gave up his local offices, and although nominated as a judge, refused to attend the trial of Charles I in January 1649. He was elected to the Council of State in 1652 and 1653 but rarely attended, living in semi-retirement in London. He resumed his seat for Cheshire when the Long Parliament was reinstated in 1659, until its dissolution in March 1660, and died on 7 April 1661.

note.label: Thomas Brockill
note.desc: Thomas Brockill, or Brockhall, born in Richmond and educated at St John's, Cambridge (BA 1639), was vicar of St. Mary, Hornby, from 1650-69. He was one of the ministers who conducted Alice Osborne Wandesford's funeral service in 1659.

note.label: James Brodricke
note.desc: James Brodricke was Alice's brother George Wandesford's footman.

note.label: Benjamin Browne
note.desc: Benjamin Browne came with Dr Samways to Alice and William Thornton's house at East Newton to take the sacrament in 1662. He was possibly related to Alice Thornton.

note.label: Joseph Browning
note.desc: Joseph Browning was a coachman who was driving a carriage containing Alice Thornton, her parents and siblings in October 1636. They were heading to Kildare, west of Dublin. The carriage was overturned on a narrow pass by a river but mercifully all passengers survived.

note.label: Mrs Bucke
note.desc: Mrs Bucke was possibly a servant in Alice Thornton's household or a local woman, who advised Alice on the pearl in her daughter Nally's eye which appeared after she had recovered from small pox in April 1667.

note.label: Cousin Bullock
note.desc: 'Cousin Bullock' is listed as a bearer of William Thornton's coffin at his funeral on 18 September 1668. He was probably a descendant of Launcelot Bullock of Holme and Margaret Thornton, the daughter of William Thornton's great grandmother, making him a cousin-by-marriage to Alice Thornton.

note.label: Mr Burrage
note.desc: Burrage or Berridge was involved in the murder of Alice Thornton's nephew Thomas Danby, allegedly over a pawned sword, near Gray's Inn, London in August 1667.

note.label: James Butler
note.desc: James Butler (born 19 October 1610) to Thomas Butler and Elizabeth Pointz was an Anglo-Irish statesman and first Earl of Ormond. He married Elizabeth Preston at Christmas 1629, by whom he had ten children; three sons and two daughters surviving to adulthood. He was brought to Ireland by Thomas Wentworth, earl of Strafford as head of government in Ireland in 1633 and was present at the meal where Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton's father became unwell in 1640, dying soon afterwards. He witnessed Wandesford's will. He commanded the Royalist forces in Ireland during the Civil War of the 1640s and subsequent Cromwellian invasion, and Alice mentions his becoming Lord Lieutenant of Ireland on the Restoration of Charles II in 1660. He died at his estate at Kingston Lacey, Dorset, on 21 July 1688.

note.label: William Cavendish
note.desc: William Cavendish, 1st Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne was born in December 1693 to Charles Cavendish and his second wife Catherine Ogle, their second but first surviving son. A writer, courtier and royalist army officer, he led his battalion, the Whitecoats, under the Royalist forces of Prince Rupert at the battle of Marston (Hessom) Moor in 1644. The Royalist army suffered a huge defeat, and the Whitecoats lost some 4,000 troops. Alice notes the tragedy of the loss and their bravery in Book 1. Cavendish died at Welbeck Abbey on Christmas Day 1676.

note.label: Katherine Stanhope Cholmley
note.desc: Katherine Stanhope Cholmley was married to Lord Robert Cholmley. Alice lists them, along with others, as friendly and helpful neighbours of the family when they returned to England from Ireland in the early 1640s, staying for some time in Cheshire before heading back to Yorkshire. She died in 1657.

note.label: Robert Cholmley
note.desc: Robert Cholmley (born 26 June 1584) was the son of Hugh Cholmley and Mary Holford. He married Katherine Stanhope. They had no children. He was MP for Cheshire in 1625. Alice lists Lord and Lady Cholmley, along with others, as friendly and helpful neighbours of the family when they returned to England from Ireland in the early 1640s, staying for some time in Cheshire before heading back to Yorkshire. He was made Earl of Leinster in 1646. He died on 8 October 1659.

note.label: Ursula Cholmley
note.desc: Ursula Cholmley (nee Thornton) was the eldest daughter of Robert Thornton and his first wife, Dorothy Metham. She was William Thorton's half-sister. She married Marmaduke Cholmley of Bransby and they had a son and two daughters. Alice Thornton called her 'my sister Cholmley'. William Thornton, on his way home from York to East Newton, stopped at Bransby Hall when he became ill with a palsy in November 1665.

note.label: Katherine Cholmley
note.desc: Katherine Stapleton (born c. 1607) was the daughter of Henry Stapleton of Wighill and Mary Forster. She married George Twisleton, who died c. 1635, and then married Henry Cholmley. They had one daughter, Henrietta. She was godmother to Alice Thornton's son, Robert, baptised in September 1662. She was buried on 14 June 1672.

note.label: Sir John Clotworthy
note.desc: John Clotworthy, 1st Viscount Massereene was an Anglo-Irish politician, son of Sir Hugh Clotworthy and Mary Langford of county Antrim. He was knighted in 1626 and married Margaret Jones, daughter of Viscount Ranelagh. They had one daughter, Mary. He was a presbyterian and opponent of Thomas Wentworth during his time as Lord Deputy of Ireland. He died in September 1665.

note.label: Thomas Comber
note.desc: Thomas Comber (born 1645) was the son of James Comber and Mary Burton of Westerham, Kent. He was

note.label: Mary Cotes
note.desc: Mary Cotes was probably a servant in Alice Thornton's household who, with Hanna Ableson, cared for her daughter Katherine in September 1666 when she had the small pox.

note.label: Roger Covell
note.desc: Roger Covell was a solicitor based at Fremlington. He was admitted to Inner Temple in 1629 and called to the bar in 1639. He was Alice Thornton's cousin-by-marriage since he was married to Anne Norton (which one?). He also acted as Alice and William Thornton's solicitor: he settled William's estate in 1662. He was buried on 12 July 1664.

note.label: John Crathorne
note.desc: John Crathorne (born c. 1634) was the son of Ralph Crathorne and his second wife Margaret Thornton, William Thornton's half-sister. He was a pall-bearer at William's funeral in 1666 along with his brother Ralph.

note.label: Margaret Thornton Crathorne
note.desc: Margaret Thornton Crathorne was the daughter of Robert Thornton and his first wife Dorothy Metham. She was William Thornton's half-sister. Around 1632 she became the second wife of Ralph Crathorne of Crathorne, and they had three sons.

note.label: Ralph Crathorne
note.desc: Ralph Crathorne (born c. 1634) was the first son of Ralph Crathorne of Crathorne and his second wife Margaret Thornton, William Thornton's half-sister. He married Anne Tunstall, and they had three sons. He was a pall-bearer at his uncle William Thornton's funeral in 1668.

note.label: Oliver Cromwell
note.desc: Oliver Cromwell (born 25 April 1599) was Lord Protector of England, Wales and Ireland during the Interregnum period of 1649 until his death in 1658. Born to Robert Cromwell and Elizabeth Steward, he was educated at Sidney Sussex College Cambridge and married Elizabeth Bourchier in 1621. They had nine children; five sons and four daughters.

note.label: Richard Cromwell
note.desc: Richard Cromwell (born 4 October 1626) was the third son, and fourth child, of Oliver Cromwell and Elizabeth Bourchier.

note.label: Robert Dagett
note.desc: Robert Daggett of Howe studied at Sidney Sussex College Cambridge then went to Oxford soon after in 1612. He became Rector of Kirklington in April 1639. Alice Thornton and her family stayed with him at Kirklington in 1644, unable to get to York or their home at Hipswell due to the ongoing Civil War. He died on 19th August 1649.

note.label: Anne Culpepper Danby
note.desc: Anne Culpeper was born on 16 September 1630 in Hollingbourne, Kent, to Thomas Culpeper and Katherine St. Leger. Circa 1652 she married Christopher Danby, son of Katherine Wandesford and Thomas Danby and Alice Thornton's nephew, making here Alice's niece-in-law. The Culpeper and Danby families were early settlers in colonial Maryland, and, according to Alice Thornton, Christopher's father did not approve of the match. By the time their first son Abstrupus was born in 1655 they had moved back to Yorkshire, and a daughter, Francilia, followed in 1659. By the late 1660s Anne Danby was living with Alice Thornton and her family at East Newton, and in 1668, according to Alice, was responsible for the slanders that had been spread regarding the marriage of Alice's daughter Nally to Thomas Comber, resulting in her being kicked out of the house by William Thornton. She died on 11 November 1695 at York.

note.label: Alice Danby
note.desc: Alice Danby was the daughter of Thomas Danby and Katherine Wandesford, and was Alice Thornton's niece.

note.label: Celia Danby
note.desc: Francilia (Celia) Danby, born 1659, was the daughter of Christopher Danby and Anne Culpeper; Alice Thornton's great-niece. Although born and brought up in Yorkshire, she moved back to colonial Maryland where her parents had met, and married Joseph Goodrich in or around 1685. They had two sons before his death in 1694. She married Thomas Parker in 1694 and died around 1696.

note.label: Christopher Danby
note.desc: Christopher Danby (born 1632/33) was the second son of Thomas Danby and Katherine Wandesford and Alice Thornton's nephew. After his mother's death in 1645 the family emigrated to Maryland and around 1652 he married Anne Culpeper without his father's permission. Christopher and Anne moved back to Yorkshire and had two children, Abstrupus (b. 1655) and Francilia (b. 1659). On his older brother Thomas's murder at Grays Inn in 1667, he became heir to his father's estate. He died in 1695.

note.label: Charles Danby
note.desc: Charles Danby (born 6 June 1643) was the son of Thomas Danby and Katherine Wandesford; and Alice Thornton's nephew. He was admitted to Gray's Inn in 166/64, and died without issue in 1672.

note.label: Francis Danby*
note.desc: Francis Danby (born 1644) was the 15th child of Thomas Danby and Katherine Wandesford. Born at Middleham Castle, he died shortly after birth. Their next son born the year after was named Francis after him.

note.label: Margaret Eure Danby
note.desc: Margaret Danby Eure was the daughter of William, 6th Lord Eure and Margaret Denton. She married Thomas Danby, son of Thomas Danby and Katherine Wandesford, in 1659. They had three children. Margaret was Alice Thornton's niece-in-law. Referred to as 'Madam Danby' in Alice's books, it was Alice's intervention in Margaret's conflicts with her sister-in-law Anne Danby that perhaps led to the slanders against Alice and Nally Thornton by Anne Danby in 1668.

note.label: Sir Thomas Danby
note.desc: Sir Thomas Danby (born c. 1610) was the son of Christopher Danby of Farnley and Frances Parker. He was knighted Sheriff of York in 1625, and elected MP for Richmond in 1640; banned from sitting in Parliament after 1642 and was fined heavily for his loyalty to Charles. He married Katherine Wandesford, by whom he had sixteen children, ten of whom survived to adulthood. He was Alice Thornton's brother-in-law. He held lands in colonial New England, and died in York in 1660.

note.label: Thomas Danby
note.desc: Thomas Danby (born 1631) was the oldest son of Sir Thomas Danby and Katherine Wandesford, and Alice Thornton's nephew. He married Margaret Eure in 1659, and they had three children. In 1660 he became MP for Malton and in 1661-62 he was the first Mayor of Leeds. He was killed in a tavern brawl in London in 1667, and his brother Christopher became heir to the Danby estate.

note.label: Conyers Darcy ?
note.desc: Conyers Darcy, 2nd Earl Holdernesse (born 1622) was the son and heir of Conyers Darcy, 1st Earl Holdernesse and Grace Rokeby. He married four times: to Catherine Fane, Frances Howard, Frances Seymour and Elizabeth Frescheville. With Frances Howard he had six children. Elected MP for Boroughbridge in 1660, becoming a peer in 1680, as Baron Conyers. He died on 13 December 1692.

note.label: Dorothy Bellasis Darcy
note.desc: Dorothy Bellasis (born 1572) was the daughter of Henry Bellasis and Ursula Fairfax. She married Conyers Darcy, 4th Lord Conyers, in 1594, with whom she had 12 children. She died on 11 May 1653 in Hornby.

note.label: Henry Darcy
note.desc: Henry Darcy (born c. 1610) was the third son of Conyers Darcy, 4th Lord Conyers and Dorothy Bellasis. He married Mary Scrope in 1628.

note.label: James Darcy
note.desc: James Darcy was the sixth son of Conyers Darcy, 4th Lord Conyers and Dorothy Bellasis. He married Isabel Wyvill. They seven children, three sons and four daughters. He died in 1673.

note.label: Francis Darley
note.desc: Francis Darley (born 1605) was the son Sir Richard Darley of Buttercrambe, Yorkshire and his second wife, Elizabeth Gates. He was William Thornton's uncle, the younger brother of Elizabeth Darley Thornton Gates. He was an executor of Alice's mother's will in 1659. He died in 1679.

note.label: Richard Darley
note.desc: Richard Darley (born c. 1602) was the third son Sir Richard Darley of Buttercrambe, Yorkshire and Elizabeth Gates. He was William Thornton's uncle, a younger brother of Elizabeth Darley Thornton Gates. He married Elizabeth Hildyard, and they had six children, five sons and a daughter. He died on 2 February 1680/81.

note.label: Don de Lan
note.desc: Don de Lan was a French page in the service of Robert Meredith, Chancellor of the Irish Exchequer. When dining at Sir Robert's in Dublin in 1637, Dan de Lon swung Alice too hard and she fell on the floor.

note.label: Elizabeth Thornton Denton
note.desc: Elizabeth Thornton was the first child of Robert Thornton and his second wife, Elizabeth Darley, and William Thornton's older sister. She married John Denton, minister of Oswaldkirk, on 8 May 1654 at East Newton. She was buried on 14 February 1669.

note.label: John Denton
note.desc: John Denton (born c. 1626) studied at Clare College Cambridge, gaining his MA in 1653. He became minister of Oswaldkirk in 1654. The same year he married Elizabeth Thornton, older sister of William Thornton. He was ejected from Oswaldkirk in 1662 for noncomformity, after which he served as curate at Holy Trinity, Stonegrave, under Alice Thornton's son-in-law Thomas Comber. Elizabeth Thornton died in 1669 and Denton remarried. His second wife Elizabeth died in 1715. With Elizabeth Thornton he had two sons, and with his second wife he had two sons and two daughters. He died on January 14 1709 and was buried at East Newton.

note.label: John Denton
note.desc: John Denton (born 1655) was the son of John Denton and Elizabeth Thornton, the cousin of William Thornton. He was baptised at Oswaldkirk, and attended Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, where he received his BA in 1677.

note.label: William Denton
note.desc: William (Willy) Denton was a son of John Denton and Elizabeth Thornton.

note.label: James Dillon
note.desc: Sir James Dillon (born c. 1600) was the youngest son of Theobald, 1st Viscount Dillon and Eleanor Tuite. An army officer, he became Commissioner of Ireland in 1627, and was elected MP for Co. Westmeath in 1634. Commissioned by Charles I in 1640 to recruit regiments from disbanded soldiers in Ireland, he was said to have been involved in the 1641 plot to seize Dublin castle. He married twice, first Elizabeth Plunkett in the 1630s, with whom he had two children, Ulick and James. Elizabeth died before 1653. His second marriage, in the early 1660s, was to Mary Ridge, a childless widow. He died no earlier than 1669.

note.label: John Dodsworth
note.desc: John Dodsworth (born 1617) was the son of John Dodsworth of Thornton Watlass and Frances Hutton, was Alice's Thornton's cousin: Alice's great-great-grandfather George Bowes of Streatlam was John's great-grandfather. He was also related to Alice by marriage; since he married Frances Lowther, aunt of Alice's sister-in-law, Christopher's wife Eleanor. John and Frances had two children, John and Helen. He died in 1662.

note.label: Mr Edrington
note.desc: Mr Edrington who attended Alice Osborn Wandesford's funeral may be the vicar of Langton who graduated from St. John's Cambridge in 1644; or a William Etherington who was instituted at St. Agatha's, Gilling, in 1665.

note.label: Katherine Farrer
note.desc: Katherine Farrer was a friend of Anne Danby who Anne tried to set up with Thomas Comber to prevent a match with Nally Thornton. Her letter to Parson Farrer, also mentioned in Alice's books, indicates that Katherine is a relation of his.

note.label: George Ferraro
note.desc: George Ferraro or Farrer was probably the minister of Thornton Watlass, made rector of St. Mary the Virgin in 1635.

note.label: Edward Fleetwood
note.desc: Edward Fleetwood was the son of Thomas Fleetwood and his second wife Bridget Spring. He studied at Oxford, and was instituted rector of Wigan in 1571; a position he held until his death on 12 October 1604. He was the brother of Alice Thornton's maternal grandmother, Joyce Fleetwood.

note.label: Sir Miles Fleetwood
note.desc: Sir Miles Fleetwood was the nephew of Alice Thornton's mother Joyce, by her brother William and Joan Clifton. Alice here confuses him with her maternal great-grandfather, Thomas Fleetwood. He died in 1641.

note.label: Jane Flouer
note.desc: Jane Flouer was a servant in Alice's household.

note.label: John Frescheville
note.desc: John Frescheville, first Baron Frescheville was the son of Sir Peter Frescheville and his first wife, Joyce Fleetwood. He was Alice's uncle, the younger half-brother of her mother Alice Osborne Wandesford. He was educated at Oxford. He married twice; Bruce Nicholls, who died in 1629 without issue and then Sarah Harington with whom he had three daughters. He was elected MP for Derbyshire in 1628, though this ended a year later when Charles I decided to rule without parliament. He was Lieutenant of Derbyshire from 1630-42, and then became a Captain in the Royalist army. He was created Baron in 1665 and died on 31 March 1682.

note.label: Sir Peter Frescheville
note.desc: Sir Peter Frescheville (baptised 14 March 1575) was the eldest son of Peter Frescheville of Staveley and his second wife Margaret Kaye. He sat in the House of Commons as MP for Derbyshire in 1601 and in 1621-22, and built Staveley Hall in 1604. He married twice, first Joyce Fleetwood, widow of Hewett Osborne, with whom he had three children, a son and two daughters; and secondly Isabel Neville who died without issue. He died on 9 April 1634 and was buried at Staveley.

note.label: Susanna Graham
note.desc: Susanna Washington Grahame (born 15 January 1618) was the daughter of William Washington and Anne Villiers. She married Ranald (Reginald) Graham of Lewisham c. 1640. He became Justice of the Peace of the North Riding of Yorkshire in 1662, and this would have brought her into the social circle of Alice Thornton, who counted her as a friend. She was godmother to Alice's youngest daughter and eighth child Joyce, born in 1665. She also gave Alice advice on medicine, and sent a carriage to take away Anne Danby from the Thornton house at East Newton to York after the scandal of 1668. She died on 26 February 1699 and was buried in the parish church at Lewisham.

note.label: Joseph Hall
note.desc: Joseph Hall (born 1574) was the son of John Hall and Winifred Bambridge. He was a religious writer, satirist, and Bishop of Exeter, and Norwich. He married Elizabeth Winniff in 1603 with whom he had eight children, six sons and two daughters. He died on 8 September 1656.

note.label: Mr Hubert
note.desc: Mr Hubert, a man of Skerries, sent ships to assist the Wandesford family's ship during a perilous crossing of the Irish Sea back to Dublin in 1639. Hubert had previously been helped by Christopher Wandesford as Justice of the Peace, who had decided a law suit in his favour.

note.label: Anne Hutton
note.desc: Anne Hutton may be the daughter of Thomas Wentworth's sister Margaret and her husband Richard Hutton. Alice describes her as a 'cousin' – a kinship that could be claimed via great-great-grandfather George Bowes, to whom the Wandesfords and Huttons were related.

note.label: Captain Innes
note.desc: An unidentified officer in the Scottish army who was stationed at Alice's mother's property after the battle of Hessom Moor in summer 1644. He pursued Alice aggressively for her hand in marriage and even plotted to abduct her with his men at one point. Possibly the same a John Innis who fought at the Battle of Dunbar in 1650.

note.label: Ralph Janson
note.desc: Ralph Janson of Thorpe was present at the wedding of Alice and William Thornton in 1651. He and Alice had previously nearly drowned crossing the Swale on the journey to Alice's aunt's house at St Nicholas in 1646.

note.label: Thomas Jenney
note.desc: Thomas Jenney was implicated in the murder of Alice Thornton's nephew Thomas Danby at Gray's Inn in 1667, but was pardoned and released from jail in October 1667.

note.label: John Lambert
note.desc: John Lambert (born 7 September 1619) was the son of Josias Lambert and his second or third wife. He was a Parliamentarian general during the English Civil War. He married Frances Lister on 10 September 1639, and they had ten children, three of whom survived to adulthood. He died on 1 March 1684.

note.label: Edward? Lassells
note.desc: Edward or Edmund Lassells was a coffin-bearer at the funeral of William Thornton in September 1668. Alice describes him as a cousin: her paternal aunt Eleanor Wandesford had married George Lassells, and so this Edward or Edmund may have been a descendant of theirs. An Edward Lassells was buried on 22 August 1675 at St. Michael le Belfrey, York, but there is no firm link.

note.label: William Laud
note.desc: William Laud (born 7 October 1573), Archbishop of Canterbury, was born in Reading to William Laud and Lucy Robinson (nee Webb). He was educated at Reading school and then Oxford and elected Archbishop of Canterbury in 1633. A royalist, he was executed on 10 January 1645.

note.label: Richard Legard
note.desc: Richard Legard was the second son of John Legard and Elizabeth Mallory. He was related to Alice Thornton via Alice's great-great-grandfather George Bowes, who married Dorothy Mallory. A barrister at Gray's Inn, he was godfather to Alice's eighth child and youngest daughter, Joyce, born and baptised in September 1665.

note.label: General Leslie
note.desc: David Leslie, 1st Lord Newark was an army officer in the employ of Alexander Leslie, first earl Leven. A key figure in the parliamentarian success at the battle of Marston Moor, he was stationed in Yorkshire, when Alice Thornton and her mother complained to him about Captain Innes, a soldier who was harassing them due to Alice's refusal to become romantically involved with him. He married Jane Yorke and they had nine children; three sons and six daughters. He died in February 1682.

note.label: George Lightfoot
note.desc: George Lightfoot was a servant in the household of Alice Osborn Wandesford, Alice Thornton's mother. He married another of her servants, Daphne Cassell. A literate man, he and Daphne were witnesses to Alice senior's will in 1659. The couple had at least one child.

note.label: Anne Loftus
note.desc: Anne Loftus (born c. 1626) was the daughter of Robert Loftus and Eleanor Ruishe, and the granddaughter of Adam Loftus, Lord Chancellor of Ireland. She and her parents lived in the household of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Lord Strafford, in the late 1630s, when she kept company with Alice Thornton and the Wentworth daughters. She married Richard Lennard Barrett c. 1653 and had four children, 2 sons and 2 daughters. She died on 4 April 1659.

note.label: Edward Loftus
note.desc: Edward Loftus (born c. 1598) was the second son of Adam Loftus, Lord Chancellor of Ireland and Sarah Bathow. He married Jane Lindley, and through her inherited Middleham Castle, Yorkshire – where Alice's sister Katherine gave birth in 1644. The Loftus, Wentworth and Wandesford families were close associates in Ireland. Edward and Jane had two children, Arthur and Sarah. He died on 11 April 1680.

note.label: Robert Loftus
note.desc: Robert Loftus of Waitwith was present at the wedding of Alice Wandesford and William Thornton in 1651. A self-described 'yeoman', he had four daughters and a son. He may have been an investor in the lead mining and smelting that was taking place in Thorpe Edge. His will, dated 29 August 1672, shows that he owed money to Christopher Wandesford, Alice Thornton's brother.

note.label: William Lowcock
note.desc: William Lowcock was rector of All Saints, Nunnington from 1658 until his death in 1678. He baptised Alice Thornton's son Robert in 1662 at the family home in East Newton.

note.label: Connor Maguire
note.desc: Connor Maguire, 2nd Baron Enniskillen (born c. 1612) was the eldest son of Brian Roe Maguire and Rose ny Neale. He married Mary Fleming and they had several sons. He was one of the conspirators in the failed plot to seize Dublin Castle during the Irish rebellion of 1641, and was executed at Tyburn on 20 February 1645.

note.label: Hugh Oge Mac Mahon
note.desc: Hugh Oge Mac Mahon (born 1606/07) was a younger son of Brian Hugh Oge Mac Mahon, Lord of Dartrey and Mary O'Neill. He was an Irish conspirator in the failed 1641 plot to seize Dublin Castle during the Irish Rebellion. He was executed at Tyburn on 22 November 1644.

note.label: Edmund Mainwaring
note.desc: Edmund Mainwaring (born c. 1579) was the second son of Randle Mainwaring and Margaret Fitton of Over Peover, Cheshire. He matriculated Brasnose College, Oxford in 1594 and All Souls in 1600. He married Jane, and they had three children, a daughter and two sons, who were baptised in York. A civil lawyer, he held various positions before becoming Chancellor of Chester in 1634. He died circa 1644.

note.label: Mrs Mainwaring
note.desc: Jane Mainwaring was the wife of Edmund Mainwaring. Her birth name is unknown but she is thought to have come from York. She and Edmund married before 1614 had three children, a daughter and two sons.

note.label: Captain Mainwaring
note.desc: Captain Mainwaring could be William Mainwaring, son of Edmund Mainwaring, killed during the Siege of Chester in 1645; or Philip Mainwaring, son of Randle Mainwaring and Jane Smith, who is referred to as a 'captaine of the horse'. Both were involved in the defence of Chester.

note.label: Sir Robert Meredith
note.desc: Robert Meredith was the son of Richard Meredith, Bishop of Leighlin and Sarah Bathow. He married Anne Usher, and they had three sons. He served as Chancellor of the Exchequer of Ireland. He died in 1668.

note.label: Margery Millbanke
note.desc: Margery Millbanke was a servant in Alice Thornton's household.

note.label: George Monck
note.desc: George Monck (born 6 December 1608) was the fourth son of Sir Thomas Monck, landowner in Devon and Elizabeth Smyth. A colonel in the Royalist army, he landed in Dublin in 1642 to quell the Irish uprising. He died on 1 January 1670.

note.label: Philip Nesbit
note.desc: Philip Nesbit, son of Philip Nesbit of York and Elizabeth Hoyle, received his Cambridge BA and MA from Corpus Christi in 1638 and 1641 held the rectorship of Kirklington from 1649-1662. He married Susan Hemmingway and they had six children, four sons and two daughters, five of whom survived childhood. He was removed from Kirklington in 1662 for refusing to subscribe to the Act of Uniformity. He died the next year, according to Alice by 'vomiting up his very excrements', and was buried at St. Martins, York on 15 October 1663.

note.label: Robert Nettleton
note.desc: Robert Nettleton was a creditor of Christopher Wandesford. William Thornton inherited this debt via his marriage to Alice.

note.label: Christopher Norton
note.desc: Christopher Wandesford (born c. 1651) was the third son of Maulger Norton and Anne Wandesford, and was Alice Thornton's first cousin.

note.label: William Norton
note.desc: William Norton was the son of Maulger Norton and Anne Wandesford, and was Alice Thornton's first cousin. He was murdered in December 1666 in London.

note.label: John Ogle
note.desc: John Ogle was implicated in the murder of Alice Thornton's nephew Thomas Danby at Gray's Inn in 1667, but was pardoned and released from jail in October 1667.

note.label: Anne Walmesley Osborne
note.desc: Anne Walmesley was the daughter of Thomas Walmesley of Dunkenhalgh. She married William Middleton and had no issue; on his death she married Edward Osborne, Alice Thornton's maternal uncle, and became his second wife. They had a son, Thomas. She was buried on 20 August 1666.

note.label: Sir Hewett Osborne
note.desc: Hewett Osborne (baptised 13 March 1566/67) was the son of Sir Edward Osborne and Anna Hewett, and Alice Thornton's maternal grandfather. A landowner and solider, he married Joice Fleetwood, and they had a son and a daughter. He owned lands at Kiveton, Yorkshire, but lived in Essex. He died in September 1599.

note.label: Lady Joyce Fleetwood Osborne
note.desc: Joyce Fleetwood was the daughter of Sir Thomas Fleetwood of The Vache and his second wife, Bridget Spring, and the maternal grandmother of Alice Thornton. She married Sir Hewett Osborne on 26 December 1588 and they had two children, Edward and Alice. He died in 1599, and on 18 October 1604 she married Peter Frescheville, and they had three children. She died in April 1619.

note.label: Christopher Parkes
note.desc: Christopher Parkes attended St. John's College Cambridge where he graduated with an MA in 1663. He was vicar of Catterick and minister of the chapel at Hipswell, Bolton-super-Swale and Hudswell.

note.label: Sir John Payton
note.desc: Sir John Payton (born 1561) was the son of Robert Payton and Elizabeth Rich. He married Alice Osborne, sister of Hewett Osborne, and so was Alice Thornton's maternal great-uncle by marriage, and they had six sons and seven daughters. He was twice elected MP for Cambridgeshire, in 1593 and in 1604, and died on 19 December 1616.

note.label: Sir William Persons
note.desc: William Persons (born c. 1570) was the son of James Persons and Catherine Fenton. He became one of the Lord Justices of Ireland after the death of Alice Thornton's father Christopher Wandesford in 1640 until 1642. He had previously been Surveyor General of Ireland and an MP for County Wicklow. He married Elizabeth Lany and they had twelve children, five sons and seven daughters. He died in January or February 1650 and is buried at St. Margaret's, Westminster.

note.label: John Plummer
note.desc: John Plummer was the man who discovered the body of George Wandesford, Alice's brother, near Catterick Bridge on the river Swale in 1651. The name 'Plummer' is attested in Easby parish registers as well as wills from Richmond, Reeth and Bedale, but this John Plummer has not been traced.

note.label: Frances Thornton Portington
note.desc: Frances Thornton was the youngest sister of Alice Thornton's husband William and Alice's sister-in-law. She was the third wife of Timothy Portington, who she married in 1663, and they had one son. She died in 1704/05.

note.label: Timothy Portington
note.desc: Timothy Portington of Malton was married three times; to Mary Pye, Mary Ruddock and Frances Thornton, the younger sister of Alice Thornton's husband William. He had a daughter, Elizabeth, with Mary Ruddock and a son with Frances Thornton. He died on 26 June 1697.

note.label: Mr Raynes
note.desc: Mr Raines was a man to whom William Thornton was in debt along with his brother-in-law Timothy Portington. Anselment postulates that this could be John Raynes of Appleton-le-Street, west of Malton, who held the manor of Malton Priory until 1665, or Thomas Raynes, an attorney and Lord Mayor of York in the 1660s.

note.label: Sir George Ratcliffe
note.desc: Sir George Ratcliffe (baptised 1593) was the son of Nicholas Ratcliffe and Margaret Marsh. He was educated at University College Oxford and entered the bar at Gray's Inn circa 1618. A cousin-by-marriage (through his second wife Anne Trappes) of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Lord Strafford, he was part of Strafford's Irish administration 1633-40, and was imprisoned in Dublin Castle after being tried for treason in 1640. George and Anne had one son, Thomas. After his release in 1642 he spent much of the rest of his life in the Netherlands, and died in 1657.

note.label: Martha Richison
note.desc: Martha Richison was a witness of Alice and William Thornton's wedding in 1651.

note.label: Jane Rimer
note.desc: Jane Rimer was a midwife who, in 1654, helped Alice Thornton's young daughter Nally through a fit.

note.label: Anne Robinson
note.desc: Anne Robinson was a maid in the Thornton household who Alice saved from choking on a goose bone in 1661.

note.label: Matthew Robinson
note.desc: Matthew Robinson graduated from the University of Cambridge in 1652 and was appointed vicar of St. Lambert, Burneston in 1651, which he held for 40 years.

note.label: Mr Robinson
note.desc: Mr. Robinson was possibly Thomas Robinson of Easby, who held land in the Richmond area.

note.label: Prince Rupert
note.desc: Prince Rupert of the Palatinate, Duke of Cumberland (born 18 December 1619) was the son of Frederick V of the Palatinate and Countess Louisa Juliana of Nassau. One of the main military commanders in the Wars of the Three Kingdoms, he never married, but had two children, with Francesca Bard, and later Margaret Hughes. He died on 29 November 1682.

persName.roleName: Prince and count of the Palatinate, Duke of Cumberland

note.label: Anne Wake Savile
note.desc: Anne Wake (baptised 19 January 1647/48) was the daughter of Robert Wake of Antwerp and London and Mabel Brokesby. She married James Savile, 2nd Earl of Sussex, and they had a son, James, who did not survive infancy. After his death in 1671 she married Fairfax Overton in April 1674. She died in 1679.

note.label: Laurence Sayers
note.desc: Laurence Sayers was a member of a recusant family in Worsall, Northallerton, whose estates had been forfeited in the 1650s. Laurence Sayer junior borrowed heavily to buy back the estates. He is possibly the same Laurence Sayer who married Catherine Burdon in 1690, who went on to have a son, Robert.

note.label: Richard Shuttleworth
note.desc: Richard Shuttleworth (born 1587) was the son of Thomas Shuttleworth and Anne Lever. In 1607 he inherited Gawthorpe Hall from his uncle Lawrence Shuttleworth. He married Fleetwood Barton with whom he had 8 sons and 4 daughters. He may also have married Judith Thorpe (Dugdale). A Parliamentarian, he was MP for Preston from 1640-48 and re-elected in 1654 during the Interregnum. He died in 1669.

note.label: Mr Sinkler
note.desc: Mr Sinkler is possibly Enoch or Henock Synkler, rector of Slingsby, educated at St. John's College Cambridge, graduating in 1633.

note.label: Lady Mary Smith
note.desc: Mary Smyth was the daughter of Hugh Smyth of Long Ashton, Somerset and Elizabeth Gorges. She married Sir Thomas Smith of Hatherton, Cheshire, and had 22 children.

note.label: Sir Thomas Smith
note.desc: Sir Thomas Smith (born c. 1595) was the son of Thomas Smith of Hatherton, Cheshire and Anne Mainwaring. Mayor of Chester from 1622 and High Sheriff in 1623, he sat as MP for Chester between 1640-44 before being barred from Parliament for his royalist support. He married Mary Smyth, and they had 22 children. He died c. 1668.

note.label: Dr Smith
note.desc: Dr. Smith was a physician who attended Alice Osborne Wandesford, Alice Thornton's mother, on her deathbed.

note.label: Sir Hugh Smithson
note.desc: Sir Hugh Smithson of Stanwick St. John, North Yorkshire, was the son of Anthony Smithson and Eleanor Catterick. He was a royalist made Baronet in 1660 by Charles II for his support. He married Dorothy Rawsthorne, and they had four sons and two daughters. According to Alice Thornton, his oldest son Jerome plotted to rape her. He died on 21 October 1670.

note.label: Jerome Smithson
note.desc: Sir Jerome Smithson, 2nd Baronet Stanwick (born 1632) was the eldest son and heir of Sir Hugh Smithson, 1st Baronet Stanwick and Dorothy Rawsthorne.. According to Alice Thornton, Jerome's father and uncle sought her hand in marriage to Jerome, but on refusal he plotted to rape and abduct Alice when she was living at Hipswell, but a man named Tom Binks informed her of the plot so she could escape. He married Mary Wingate, and they had a son and a daughter. He died in 1684.

note.label: Uncle Smithson
note.desc: Uncle Smithson is one of Sir Jerome's Smithson's paternal uncles, Francis, Richard or John. He helped his brother Hugh Smithson in a bid to marry his nephew Jerome to Alice Thornton in the late 1640s or early 1650s.

note.label: Charles II
note.desc: Charles Stewart, Charles II of England, Scotland and Ireland (born 29 May 1630) was the son and heir Charles I and Henrietta Maria. He was King of Scotland 1649-51 and King of England, Scotland and Ireland from the Restoration in 1660 until his death in 1685. He married Catherine of Braganza, but had no legitimate issue. He fathered some 9 illegitimate children. He died on 6 February 1689.

note.label: Mr Thomson
note.desc: Mr Thomson of Catterick Bridge owned the house where the body of George Wandesford, drowned in the Swale while attempting to cross it on horseback, was laid after its recovery in 1651.

note.label: Christopher Thornton
note.desc: Christopher Thornton (1667): the 9th child of Alice and William Thornton. He was born at Newton, 11th Nov. 1667 and baptized on the 12th. He contracted small pox and died on 1 Dec. 1667 and was buried at Stonegrave on the 2nd.

note.label: Joyce Thornton
note.desc: Joyce Thornton (1665-6): the 8th child of Alice and William Thornton. Joyce was born on 23rd Sept. 1665 at Newton and baptized on the 28th. She fell ill on 20th Jan. 1666 with a cold and red spots and died on 26th Jan. Buried on the 27th in Stonegrave.

note.label: Robert Thornton
note.desc: Robert Thornton (1662-92): the 7th child and 3rd son of Alice and William Thornton. He was born on 19 Sept. 1662 at East Newton. He was educated first by John Denton, then by the reverend John Burton at Sutton-on –the-Forest, then entered Sidney Sussex College in April 1680, then University College. In 1687 he became the rector of Oddington but resigned it later that year. In 1691 he took over the living of Boldon in the diocese of Durham but actually resided at the Deanery in Durham with his sister and her husband, Thomas Comber. He caught a cold and died there on 4 June 1692, aged 29. He was buried in the Chapel of the Nine Altars, Durham Cathedral where there is a memorial to him, erected by his sister, Alice Thornton Comber, in XXXX.

note.label: Robert Thornton
note.desc: Robert Thornton (XXXX-1637), father of William Thornton. His first marriage was to Dorothy Metham and they had four daughters, one of whom died in infancy. He then married Elizabeth Darley with whom he had William and Richard (twins), Thomas, John, Elizabeth, Mary and Frances. He was buried at Stonegrave on 27 May 1637.

note.label: Thomas Thornton
note.desc: Thomas Thornton (born 1626) was the son of Robert Thorton and Elizabeth Darley, and the younger brother of William Thornton, so was Alice's brother-in-law.

note.label: William Thornton
note.desc: William Thornton, son of Alice and William Thornton (1660): their 6th child and 2nd son was born and baptized at St Nicholas on 17 April 1660, died on 28 April of the small pox and was buried on the 29th at Easby, in the same grave as his unnamed sister.

note.label: Mr Tirrill
note.desc: Mr Tirrill of Hoddesdon was a chief mourner at the funeral of Alice Thornton's brother John Wandesford in 1664.

note.label: Barbara Todd
note.desc: Barbara Todd was a maid of Anne Culpeper Danby, Alice Thornton's niece-by-marriage. According to Alice, she was one of the perpetrators of the slanders faced by Alice and her daughter Nally around Nally's marriage to Thomas Comber in 1668.

note.label: Mr Troutbeck
note.desc: Young Mr Troutbeck was a man who gave Alice Thornton's sick mother advice while Alice was in labour with her daughter Elizabeth in February 1654.

note.label: Elizabeth I
note.desc: Elizabeth I (born 7 September 1533) was Queen of England from 1558 until her death in 1603. The daughter of Henry VIII and his second wife Anne Boleyn, she never married. Alice Thornton notes that her mother Alice Osborne Wandesford was born during Elizabeth's reign. She died on 24 March 1603.

note.label: Sir Christopher Wandesford
note.desc: Sir Christopher Wandesford (d. 1591) was the son of Francis Wandesford of Kirklington and Jane Fulthorp; Alice Thornton's great-grandfather. He married Elizabeth Bowes and they had four children; three sons and a daughter. He diewd on 11 July 1591.

note.label: Christopher Wandesford*
note.desc: Christopher Wandesford (1617-27) was the son of Sir Christopher Wandesford and Alice Osborne; Alice Thornton's older brother. He died age 10 in 1627. Alice's brother born in 1628 was named after him.

note.label: William Wandesford
note.desc: William Wandesford of Pickhill was the son of Richard Wandesford and Muriel Yoward; and was a cousin of Alice's father William Wandesford. He was living in Ireland at the time of Christopher Wandesford's death in 1640, and was a witness to his will as well as executor of his estate. He married Elizabeth Askwith and they had three sons.

note.label: Luke Wastell
note.desc: Luke Wastell was the third son of Leonard Wastell of Scorton and Anne Danby of Kirkby Knowle. His brother John was a Parliamentarian and MP for Northallerton. He married twice; first Sarah Laton and then Elizabeth Pattison.

note.label: Robert Webster
note.desc: Robert Webster of Nunnington was a witness at Alice and William Thornton's marriage in 1651.

note.label: Elizabeth Rhodes Wentworth
note.desc: Elizabeth Rhodes Wentworth (c. 1614-88) was the daughter of Godfrey Rhodes and Anne Lewknor. In around 1632 she became the third wife of Thomas Wentworth, 1st Lord Strafford, and they had two children, Thomas and Margaret. She was also step-mother to Wentworth's children with Arabella Holles. She died in 1688.

note.label: William Wentworth
note.desc: William Wentworth 2nd Lord Raby 2nd Earl Strafford (1626-1695) was born on 8 June 1626 to Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl Strafford and his second wife Arabella Holles, their first child and only son. He married twice; first Henrietta Maria Stanley; and second Henrietta de la Rochfoucauld. He died without issue on 16 October 1695.

note.label: Philadelphia Carey Wharton
note.desc: Lady Wharton was probably Philadelphia Carey (d. 1654), daughter of Robert Carey and Elizabeth Trevannion. She was a lady-in-waiting to Princess Elizabeth, Queen of Bohemia and married Sir Thomas Wharton of Aske Hall in April 1611 and they had two sons, Philip and Thomas. She died at Easby in 1654.

note.label: Ralph Widdrington
note.desc: Ralph Widdrington (1614/15-88) was the son of Lewis Widdrington of Cheesburn Grange, Northumberland and Anne Lawson. He attended Morpeth School and was then admitted to Christ's College Cambridge in 1632. He was admitted to Gray's Inn in 1641, before being ordained and tutoring at Christ's, where he taught Alice Thornton's younger brother John Wandesford. He died at Christ's on 10 June 1688.

note.label: Sir Christopher Wyvill
note.desc: Sir Christopher Wyvill, 3rd Baronet of Constable Burton (1614-81), was the eldest son and heir of Marmaduke Wyvill and Isabel Gascoigne. He married Ursula Darcy on 12 December 1636, and the couple had 12 children; six of whom died before them (two daughters and four sons), and six (three sons and three daughters) survived them. He wrote an elegy for Alice's brother George Wandesford, who drowned in the Swale in 1651. He was elected MP for Richmond in 1659 and returned to the Long Parliament in 1660. He was buried with his wife, who died in 1680, at Masham on 8 February 1681.
